text:
Q: Can LightningChart Python charts be embedded in an iframe / WebView (pywebview)? A:

Yes, as long as you use the “live server URL” approach. LightningChart Python can serve the chart via a local HTTP server. The docs describe chart.open(method="link") as starting the same kind of live rendering as live=True, but instead of opening a browser window it returns a URL that you can embed into your own UI. Here is an example:

import lightningchart as lc
import webview

chart = lc.ChartXY()
series = chart.add_line_series()
series.add([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], [10, 20, 15, 25, 30])

url = chart.open(method="link") 

webview.create_window("LightningChart", url, width=1200, height=800)
webview.start()

Link to PyQT example: PyQt Documentation

Q: Keep "duplicate" files after translation in git instead of merging them A:

This should be simple enough using the subtree merge strategy option (not to be confused with the subtree merge strategy):

git mv src en/src
git commit -m 'Move English src to subdirectory'
git fetch url-to-the-other-repo
git merge -X subtree=ptbr/ FETCH_HEAD

If you need to continuously pull from the fork, consider adding a named remote to your repo first. Alternatively, you might also want to look into git subtree:

Subtrees allow subprojects to be included within a subdirectory of the main project, optionally including the subproject’s entire history.

[…]

They are also not to be confused with using the subtree merge strategy. The main difference is that, besides merging the other project as a subdirectory, you can also extract the entire history of a subdirectory from your project and make it into a standalone project. Unlike the subtree merge strategy you can alternate back and forth between these two operations. If the standalone library gets updated, you can automatically merge the changes into your project; if you update the library inside your project, you can "split" the changes back out again and merge them back into the library project.

git subtree -P ptbr/ add url-to-the-other-repo branch-to-import

Q: How to route to a specific node based on tool return in LangGraph A:

The challenge is that any tool node that returns a Command including a goto keyword automatically creates a dynamic edge. For example in my code I have:

@tool(infer_schema=True)
def reposition_playback(
    state: Annotated[DocumentState, InjectedState("document_state")],
    context: Annotated[Any, InjectedToolArg] = None,
    tool_call_id: Annotated[str, InjectedToolCallId],
) -> Command | str:
    ...
return Command(update={
        'position': result.index,
        'messages': [ToolMessage(
            content='success',
            tool_call_id=tool_call_id,
        ),
],
    },
    goto='final')

That will inherently create an edge from the tool call node to final. If I set up a conditional edge router, that will create a second edge creating parallel execution.

There are a couple approaches to avoid this:

State based routing

You could have some element in your state that controls where you route to:

class state(TypedDict):
    messages: typing.Annotated[list[BaseMessage], operator.add]
    route: str = ""


@tool
def tool_that_routes(    tool_call_id: Annotated[str, InjectedToolCallId],)-> Command:
    return Command(update = {
        'messages': [ToolMessage(tool_call_id=tool_call_id, content='success')],
        'route': 'some_node'
    })


def tool_router(state:State)->str
    if state['route']: return state['route']
    return 'default_node'

I do not actually like this approach. You need to somehow clear out state.route. It gets really clunky if your graph is complicated that multiple branches might be wanting to use the routing mechanism. It also feels like it is defeating the intent of the Command mechanism.

Always return goto

Another option is to always return goto from your nodes and avoid the conditional edge router entirely.

Wrap the tool node

The approach I have taken is to wrap the tool node and look for the Command in the result of the tool node. This works when you wrap the tool node but not in a conditional edge router because in wrapping the tool node you get to look at the Command directive before it is swallowed by the graph internals and turned into a dynamic edge. At least in my experience *ToolNode * appears to return a list containing the Command object even though my tool returns a single Command. In the interest of robustness I support both approaches. Here's my tool wrapper:

async def our_tool_node(state:GraphState, runtime:Runtime) -> Command | typing.Sequence[Command]:
    node =  ToolNode(TOOLS)
    default_destination = 'llm_call'
    result = await node.ainvoke(state)
    match result:
        case Command(goto=dest) | [Command(goto=dest)]:
            return result # already includes a destination
        case Command(update=update) | [Command(update=update)]:
            return Command(goto=default_destination, update=update)
        case Command():
            raise RuntimeError('A command we do not know how to handle; for example Send API')
        case _:
            return Command(goto=default_destination, update=result)

Then my build_graph attaches no outgoing edges from the tool node at all.

Q: Plugin [id: 'com.android.application', version: '7.2.0', apply: false] was not found in any of the following sources A:

I ran into the same issue. What I tried:

  • changed the gradle version, changed the gradle plugin version
  • changed repositories where packages are searched
  • set proxy settings in gradle.properties file
  • set proxy settings in Windows 10 network settings

None of this helped me, and I installed a proxy program that can wrap the traffic of individual applications on the computer, and it worked! It was a Proxyfire program - it has a 30-day free version. The problem of accessing Google services in my case is related to local restrictions.

Q: Spring boot how to use Hikari auto configuration but set username/password at runtime A: 
  @ConfigurationProperties(prefix = "spring.datasource.hikari")
  @Bean
  @Primary
  public DataSource dataSource(String username,String password) {
     return DataSourceBuilder.create().username(username).password(password).build();
  }

and use these in yml/property file without giving username and password property.

spring:
    profiles: dev
    # Development database configuration
    datasource.hikari:
        driverClassName: oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver
        jdbcUrl: jdbc:oracle:thin:@url:1621:sid
        type: com.zaxxer.hikari.HikariDataSource
        connectionTimeout:40000

This will work. Let me know if it doesn't work for you.
